title: 110_hr5779
content: The Act titled "Social Security Forever Act of 2008" imposes a tax on wages exceeding the contribution and benefit base. The "Social Security Forever Act of 2008" imposes a 3% tax on wages exceeding the contribution and benefit base for both employees and employers. The "Social Security Forever Act of 2008" imposes a 3% excise tax on employers for wages exceeding the contribution and benefit base. A 3% tax is imposed on employees for wages exceeding the contribution and benefit base under the "Social Security Forever Act of 2008". A 3% tax is imposed on employee representatives for wages exceeding the contribution and benefit base under the "Social Security Forever Act of 2008". An excise tax of 3% is imposed on employers for wages exceeding the contribution and benefit base under the Social Security Act. Additionally, a tax on self-employment income is also imposed for wages received in excess of the contribution and benefit base. A 6% tax is imposed on self-employment income exceeding the contribution and benefit base under the Social Security Act. Conforming amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code to accommodate this tax. Amendments are made to various sections of the Internal Revenue Code to accommodate a 6% tax on self-employment income exceeding the contribution and benefit base under the Social Security Act. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code include changes to section 6053(b) regarding remuneration paid after December 31, 2008, and self-employment income for taxable years beginning after the same date. SEC. 3. SIGNATURES ON TREASURY SECURITIES. This section amends the United States Code to require that every obligation issued or guaranteed under this chapter must bear facsimile signatures of the President of the United States and the Secretary of the Treasury. Effective three months after the enactment of this Act.
